--- German Viscuso <netquake@...> wrote:
> I run into Soccerbots site some months ago and I
> liked it very much. But I
> didn't have the opportunity to check your work

I had nothing to do with developing Soccerbots (if
that's what you're saying).  I'm just making some
minor adaptations to it to use with NEAT.  It was
developed by some folks at Carnegie Mellon University
and Georgia Tech.

> mainly because I need to work
> with the RobotSoccer simulator developed by Dr Jun
> Jo for competition (you
> can download it here
> http://www.fira.net/soccer/simurosot/overview.html).
> I've done work exclusively for this league
> (Simurosot 5x5) so we have to get
> used to that particular simulator. 

Ah, okay.

> I'm not planning
> to work with real robots
> because we cannot afford any of that around here.

They are expensive, aren't they? :)

> One of the main disadvantages for applying a
> neuroevolution technique with
> this simulator is that you can only run the
> simulator in real time (no
> offline fast non-graphic simulation available) so it
> should take a long time
> and patience.

Yes...that is a big disadvantage.  Soccerbots has a
graphics-off mode, which is many times faster than
graphical mode.  It's a shame you're stuck with using
that particular simulator.

> Anyway I'm interested in your work specially if
> you'll be doing
> neuroevolution, perhaps we can share some material
> later on when I have
> something to share! ;-) (we should discuss what are
> our points in common,
> perhaps we can establish a common NEAT framework for
> 5x5).

Well, we're primarily interested in game board
domains, but we thought it would be a good idea to
integrate a robot control domain into our
implementation, and robot soccer seemed like a good
one.  At least we're both interested in domains with
similar field dimensions and similar team sizes.

I don't know if you've been following the XML
discussion, or have dipped back into the message
archive, but if we can agree on a common format for
chromosomes and/or networks, we would easily be able
to share populations between implementations, no
matter their platform or language.

Derek
